doc.title: 2H and 2026 still risky - UW
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-28/2H and 2026 still risky - UW2H and 2026 still risky - UW_2025-08-28

passages.text: We tweak our ZIM/HLAG sets post 2Q. At ZIM, we expect 3Q EBITDA up QoQ, with 3Q benefiting from revenue recognition delay, whilst 4Q could be very weak on seasonality and tariffs. We think 3Q dividend will be the last one for a while, which could take out the quarterly dividend support to shares.

\*\*Invite\*\* Back to school on the 5th- 9th of Sept - We are hosting virtual fireside chats with IRs/ Management of DHL, KNIN, DSV, NTG, Hapag- Lloyd, and InPost. For the full schedule and to register: click here

3Q to benefit from rev recognition delay. 4Q remains the big risk factor. As confirmed by ZIM management, 2Q did not fully benefit from the rate strength in the second half of the quarter, which should support 3Q. Additionally, HLAG commented that, following the recent extension of the 90- day pause between the US and China, bookings picked up in the following days and may lead to a mini- rush on the trade lane, where previously no peak season was expected. However, the outlook for 2H remains highly uncertain. A lot will depend on the de- escalation of tariff negotiations and on possible inflationary pressures impacting consumer purchasing power. The solid 1H volume outlook reflects some element of front- loading from US shippers and also implies that some of the inventory build in 2024 has not been depleted, so volumes might slow down in 2H, driving spot rate normalization.

Rates should continue to soften in 2H. Red Sea reopening still a risk for 2026. WCI spot rates have been declining WoW since mid- June, and we see little support to rates to year end, as also outlined by Loadstar, which commented that "The extension of the US- China tariff truce to 10 November is unlikely to improve transpacific ocean rates, despite a planned increase on 1 September, as front- loading is mostly complete and carriers refuse to enforce capacity discipline." Furthermore, whilst a 90- day pause is in place until 10th November, applicable tariffs of 30% on China to US trades do represent a significant higher level vs the past. Furthermore, we highlight that there is significant weak seasonality in the September- December period with rates down 15- 20% historically vs peak August, which will also weigh this year. Possible front loading In September would only anticipate volumes for a weaker 4Q. Red Sea reopening now expected by YE 25, but remains an overhang for the sector going into 2026 as HSD% of capacity might be released. We also believe that inflationary pressure in the US might start to more in 2026 than 2025 as importers benefit from a grace period until October filling warehouses ahead of the Christmas peak.
This research report has been prepared in whole or in part by equity research analysts based outside the US who are not registered/qualified as research analysts with FINRA.
Please see analyst certifications and important disclosures beginning on page 13. Completed: 27- Aug- 25, 17:40 GMT Released: 28- Aug- 25, 03:00 GMT Restricted - External
European Transportation NEUTRAL Unchanged

ZIM - 2Q EBITDA a c4% headwind to FY25 consensus, as ZIM suffers from higher US- China exposure: ZIM reported 2Q25 adj. EBITDA of \(\) 472\mathsf{mn}\(\) 15% below Bloomberg consensus of\)\\(556\mathsf{mn}\) (BarcE \(\) 623\mathsf{mn}\(. ZIM has a much higher exposure to the US- China trade at\)\epsilon 24- 28\%\(of volumes, vs. HLAG at\)\epsilon 5\%\(, and this was evident in ZIM's 2Q volumes and rates which were heavily impacted by the tariff - led volatility. 2Q saw average rates at\)\\(1,479\) vs. BarcE at \(\) 1,511\(\) - 17\%\(QoQ vs. Maersk - 7\% and HLAG - 11\%. Volumes were down by\)6\%\(yoy despite capacity up YoY, whereas Maersk and HLAG 2Q volumes grew\)+4\%\(and\)+12\%\(yoy, respectively. Management commented that the surge in TP bookings in May was short- lived, and that current TP demand remains relatively weak. 2Q was also impacted by the spillover effect from weak rates in March (WCI down\)\epsilon 20\%\(MoM), and did not benefit fully from the stronger rates in the 2nd half of 2Q, which should benefit 3Q to some degree due to revenues being recognised over the journey. At 2Q, ZIM once again reduced its volume outlook for FY25 from LSD YoY growth to now expected flat volumes YoY, after downgrading its guidance at 1Q from single digit to LSD. According to management, the reduced volume outlook is a factor of both a tougher comp for ZIM in 2H25 and a 3Q25 peak season that is expected to be weaker YoY.

3Q could be the last dividend for a while as we see negative NI in 4Q25/2026. As we expected post 1Q results, ZIM upgraded the low end of the guidance, but kept the upper end given the uncertainty ahead vs our expectations of a full guidance increase. The FY25 adj. EBITDA guidance increased by 5% at the midpoint to a range of \(\) 1.8bn\(to\) \ \(2.2bn\) (prev. \(\) 1.6bn\(to\) \ \(2.2bn\) ), but still sits \(3\%\) below BBG consensus of \(\) 2.07bn\(. ZIM no longer expects a strong peak season in 3Q, given ongoing uncertainty regarding tariffs between US and China, and with some front- loading having already taken place from US shippers. Management thinks the bulk of the peak could already be behind us. With supply now re- instated on the TP, ZIM also expects continued downward pressure on freight rates in 2H25, with 4Q remaining a big unknown as we see across the carriers. In our view, ZIM faces greater idiosyncratic risk vs. Maersk/HLAG in 2H25 given its tough YoY comps and its much larger US exposure. The mid- point of ZIM's new FY25 guidance implies 2H25 EBITDA down 40% vs 1H, a much steeper decline vs. Maersk/HLAG implied at - 25%/- 28% given more exposure to TP and spot rates. We don't rule out some upside risk to the guidance should 3Q/4Q be stronger than expected on front loading. We lower our FY25 EBITDA by \(c10\%\) to \(c\) 2.3bn from \(\) 2.3bn\(before, to reflect the 2Q miss vs. our numbers, but

our FY estimate remaining in upper end of the guidance. We model for a significant slowdown in rates by year end and for volumes to be slightly down YoY given its concentrated exposure to TP. We also note that ZIM was already burning net cash in 2Q25/1H25 and we see leverage growing above 2. In 2020. We lower our PT for ZIM to \(\) 13.3\(prev.\) \ \(14.8\) . ZIM valuation remains a complex exercise but we don't see value in the shares, with downside risk from demand supply in 4Q25 and 2026E. Quarterly dividends have been key reach catalysts in FY21, FY2 and FY24. However, we expect 3Q25 to be the last dividend to be paid as we expect negative net income in FY26. The stock would trade on a \(2\%\) divi yield on our 3Q25 estimate. On May EV/EBITDA basis, we see ZIM trading on a 2x our FY25E, but 4x in FY26E, above the historical through-the-cycle multiple. Risks to our rating remain from a stronger trading environment driven by regulatory changes and any news flow on ZIM MBO (see here).
FIGURE 3. Implied 2H EBITDA downgrades across Container Shipping

Hapag- Lloyd - FY25 tweaks to reflect narrowing of guidance at 2Q: HLAG reported 2Q25 EBITDA of €711mn, \(3\%\) below co- consensus of €730mn, as earnings were impacted by operational issues at ports and a three digit USD million cost headwind from the Gemini network transition. HLAG management narrowed its outlook for FY25 EBITDA to €2.5- 3.4bn, prev. €2.4- 3.9bn (FY24A €4.6bn). The midpoint of the new guidance is a \(6\%\) cut, but sits broadly in line with co- consensus. The outlook was narrowed to reflect elevated risks in 2H, as HLAG sees front- loading and higher permanent tariffs as potentially slowing the demand in 2H25. Post 2Q results, we lower our EBIT to €667mn from €757mn (- 12%), slightly below consensus but broadly in line with the midpoint of the new FY25 guided range of €0.2- 1.1bn. The midpoint of the new guidance reflects a similar 2H vs 1H EBITDA drop between Maersk and Hapag- Lloyd, however at 2Q results messaging around 2H differed slightly, with Maersk not seeing any front- loading in 1H while Hapag- Lloyd did.

Less of a 3Q QoQ uplift at Hapag- Lloyd. At Maersk we forecast an \(11\%\) sequential uplift on 3Q group EBITDA vs. 2Q. Whereas at Hapag- Lloyd we only forecast a \(3\%\) QoQ improvement. Both Maersk and Hapag- Lloyd mentioned that expect rates in \(3Q > 2Q\) , however during the 2Q conference call HLAG stated that in absolute terms 3Q EBITDA will be at least in line with 2Q, but yet to be seen if better, as 2Q benefited from some positive one- offs that will not repeat in 3Q. We see higher downside risk at HLAG, as \(c27\%\) of its volumes are into the US (China to US at \(5\%\) of this) vs. Maersk with \(c15\%\) exposure to the US overall. We think macro risks remain, with our economists highlighting the first signs of US macro slowdown emerging: see The economic consequences of the deal. We see positives from HLAG's cost program coming in FY26, but we expect limited tailwinds in FY25 following 1H25 which saw sizeable cost headwinds from the Gemini transition. PT down to €92/share from €93 on lower estimates.

Shipping Companies are relaxed on demand/supply. According to Loadstar, the current orderbook is almost \(c32\%\) of the in- service fleet, the highest level since 2010, with another 1 million TEUs of pending ship orders due to be added before year end. The last time the orderbook ratio exceeded this level (c2004- 2009), it ended in a decade- long supply overhang that took 10 years to clear. In our view, the degree of overcapacity in the mid- term will depend on future capacity management. HLAG's CEO does not think we will see a massive imbalance between supply and demand in 2026, according to Shipping Watch. On the 2Q HLAG conference call, management elaborated that it expects considerable scrapping even between now and the

end of FY27/into FY27, so the net increase of scrapping will not be as extreme as what orderbook implies. HLAG expects scrapping to be driven by increasing environmental regulation and an increasing number of vessels \(>25\) years, while pre- covid the average age of a scrapped ship was below 25. On the orderbook, HLAG says it is high but does cover a much longer period than usual given the elongated delivery times due to constrained shipyards.

Whereas we remain less optimistic on industry capacity management. The high average age of the fleet and possible future environmental regulations are often perceived as triggers for scrapping to pick up in the near future. However, as we outline in our note Shipping rules: IMO navigates to messy middle (22 April 2025), we remain sceptical on IMO driving significant capacity scrapping in the near term. The currently agreed framework should start to change the economic decision- making for fuel mix in the medium term, but provides limited incentives to shift to greener fuels today. It also remains to be seen if the IMO will be implemented, with the US threatening retaliation against countries that support the new global climate agreement, as outlined in this article. Scrapping is also seen as a lever to manage overcapacity. However, on this point we flag that the average age of the container fleet (TEU- weighted) is 11.0 years as of Jul- 25, and \(25\) years, whilst the orderbook continues to grow at \(29\%\) despite a major \(+11\%\) delivery increase in FY24, which has been absorbed for now by the Red Sea closure. We also remain sceptical on whether there will be enough scraypard capacity if demand picks up, especially with the Hong Kong convention now in place.

We expect a challenging demand/supply outlook ahead, with 2027/28 deliveries increasing again. We don't expect scrapping to pick up to \(3\%\) of capacity in the near term, and we expect at least 2- 3 quarters of challenging rate conditions once the Red Sea re- opens, as it will also take time to return vessels to lessors and then more time for vessels to be sent to scraypards. However, even if scrapping picks up in 2027, we still expect the challenging oversupply backdrop to continue into that year from 2026, as 2027 should see another big year of new deliveries following the orders placed in FY24. According to Clarksons, despite \(+11\%\) of newbuild capacity in 2024, capacity is still expected to grow HSD p.a. on average from 2025- 29, peaking with \(10\%\) capacity growth in 2028.

Given continued oversupply in the container shipping market, we expect earnings to turn negative again into 2025 and 2026 as the Red Sea crisis should ease and oversupply kicks in, until the industry can work through the oversupply of vessels (delayed by the RS congestion) that was created by the re-ordering spree fueled during the pandemic years.
Upside case EUR 153.00
Our upside case is derived by applying a 1.66x EV/IC 2025e multiple to our estimates.
Downside case EUR 43.00
Our downside case is derived by applying a 0.55x EV/IC 2025e multiple to our estimates.
Upside/Downside scenarios

Valuation Methodology: We value Hapag- Lloyd based on the relationship between ROIC and EV/IC. Our price target of €92 is based on a 0.92x multiple applied to our Invested Capital estimate in 2025 as we anticipate negative EBIT in 2026, with negative ROIC vs a cost of capital of €7%. Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: More effective capacity management measures improving the supply- demand imbalance. Successful execution of Hapag- Lloyd's terminal and infrastructure acquisitions. Lower unit cost through successful cost reduction programs. Lower bunker fuel costs. Active or passive impact of industry consolidation.
Valuation Methodology: We value ZIM on a 0.7x EV/IC applied to our average 2025E/26e IC to reflect our view of significant oversupply risk in 2025 and 2026 assuming the Red Sea disruption eases.

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: ZIM has high operating leverage ( \(100 on rates impacts 2024E EBITDA by\) 360mn, all else equal). Stronger than expected global economic growth and hence trade volume growth, stronger than expected freight rates due to capacity- demand balance and bunker oil price movements that are recovered through freight rates are upside risks to our price target. Downside risks include ZIM's expansion strategy potentially diluting earnings, the new vessel leasing plan potentially increasing operational and financial leverage, systems failure leading to increased costs and/or indeed a geopolitical event disrupting operations.
Source: Barclays Research

We, Marco Limite and Andrew Lobbenberg, hereby certify (1) that the views expressed in this research report accurately reflect our personal views about any or all of the subject securities or issuers referred to in this research report and (2) no part of our compensation was, is or will be directly or indirectly related to the specific recommendations or views expressed in this research report.

Overweight - The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Equal Weight - The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Underweight - The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Positive - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are improving.
Neutral - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
Negative - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are deteriorating.

Historical stock prices and price targets may have been adjusted for stock splits and dividends.

**Valuation Methodology:** Our valuation is based on the relationship between EV/IC and ROIC. We apply 0.4x 2025e invested capital for the group to reflect our view that returns will rebase well below the cost of capital over the next three years as the market moves to oversupply against a weakening demand backdrop post the strong pandemic trading. We then add other assets and deduct net debt and minorities to arrive at our price target.

**Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target:** AP Moller Maersk is principally involved in the world trade market. The main upside risks are that the integrated container shipping strategy delivers value, with better supply management and global supply chain complexity continues to absorb effective capacity. A prolonged trade downturn would leave the risks to our forecasts and valuation to the downside.

Valuation Methodology: We value Hapag- Lloyd based on the relationship between ROIC and EV/IC. Our price target of €92 is based on a 0.92x multiple applied to our Invested Capital estimate in 2025 as we anticipate negative EBIT in 2026, with negative ROIC vs a cost of capital of €7%.

Risks which May impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: More effective capacity management measures improving the supply- demand imbalance. Successful execution of Hapag- Lloyd's terminal and infrastructure acquisitions. Lower unit cost through successful cost reduction programs. Lower bunker fuel costs. Active or passive impact of industry consolidation.
Stock Rating: UNDERWEIGHT  Industry View: NEUTRAL  Closing Price: USD 14.47 (26- Aug- 2025)
Rating and Price Target Chart - USD (as of 26- Aug- 2025)  Currency=USD
Source: IDC, Barclays Research  Link to Barclays Live for interactive charting
On 27-Aug-2022, prior to any intra-day change that may have been published, the rating for this security was Equal Weight, and the adjusted price target was 63.00.
Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
*This is the closing price referenced in the publication, which may not be the last available closing price at the time of publication.
Historical stock prices and price targets may have been adjusted for stock splits and dividends.

**Valuation** **Methodology:** We value ZIM on a 0.7x EV/IC applied to our average 2025E/26e IC to reflect our view of significant oversupply risk in 2025 and 2026 assuming the Red Sea disruption eases.

**Risks** **which** **May** **Impede** **the** **Achievement** **of** **the** **Barclays** **Research** **Valuation** **and** **Price** **Target:** ZIM has high operating leverage ($100 on rates impacts 2024E EBITDA by $360mn, all else equal). Stronger than expected global economic growth and hence trade volume growth, stronger than expected freight rates due to capacity-demand balance and bunker oil price movements that are recovered through freight rates are upside risks to our price target. Downside risks include ZIM's expansion strategy potentially diluting earnings, the new vessel leasing plan potentially increasing operational and financial leverage, systems failure leading to increased costs and/or indeed a geopolitical event disrupting operations.

Sustainable Investing Related Research: There is currently no globally accepted framework or definition (legal, regulatory or otherwise) of, nor market consensus as to what constitutes a 'sustainable', 'ESG', 'green', 'climate- friendly' or an equivalent company, investment, strategy or consideration or what precise attributes are required to be eligible to be categorised by such terms. This means there are different ways to evaluate a company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.
